meteorShowers.name: Quadrantids
meteorShowers.about: The Quadrantid meteor shower peaks in January and is known for its intense but short-lived display. It seems to radiate from the constellation Bo√∂tes.

meteorShowers.name: Lyrids
meteorShowers.about: The Lyrids occur in April, with meteors appearing to originate from the constellation Lyra. They are associated with Comet C/1861 G1 Thatcher.

meteorShowers.name: Eta Aquarids
meteorShowers.about: Active in May, the Eta Aquarids are linked to Halley's Comet. They appear to come from the constellation Aquarius.

meteorShowers.name: Perseids
meteorShowers.about: One of the most popular showers, the Perseids peak in August. They radiate from the constellation Perseus and are associated with Comet 109P/Swift-Tuttle.

meteorShowers.name: Draconids
meteorShowers.frequency: Active annually, variable intensity, occasional meteor storms
meteorShowers.about: The Draconids peak in October and seem to come from the constellation Draco. They are associated with Comet 21P/Giacobini-Zinner.

meteorShowers.name: Orionids
meteorShowers.about: Active in October, the Orionids radiate from the constellation Orion. They are remnants of Halley's Comet.

meteorShowers.name: Taurids
meteorShowers.frequency: Active annually, separate branches for Northern and Southern Taurids, peaks in late October and early November
meteorShowers.about: The Taurids have two branches (North and South) and peak in November. They appear to come from the constellation Taurus.

meteorShowers.name: Leonids
meteorShowers.frequency: Active annually, peak around November 17-18, periodic meteor storms
meteorShowers.about: The Leonids peak in November and are associated with Comet 55P/Tempel-Tuttle. They radiate from the constellation Leo.

meteorShowers.name: Geminids
meteorShowers.frequency: Active annually, peak around December 13-14, one of the most reliable meteor showers
meteorShowers.about: The Geminids are one of the best showers, peaking in December. They seem to originate from the constellation Gemini and are not associated with a comet but an asteroid.

meteorShowers.name: Ursids
meteorShowers.about: Active in December, the Ursids appear to come from the constellation Ursa Minor.
